# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here is the solution in Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(input::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(input, " ")
    output = ""
    for word in words
        if length(output) + length(word) > text_width
            write(output * "\n")
            output = word
        else
            output *= " " * word
        end
    end
    return output
end
```
This function `wrap_string` takes a string and an optional integer for the width of each line. It splits the input string into words, then iterates through them. If adding the current word to the existing output would exceed the text width, it starts a new line by appending a newline character to the output, then sets the output as just the current word. If adding the current word to the existing output does not exceed the text width, it adds a space and the word to the end of the output. Finally, the function returns the complete output string.

Example usage: 
```julia
println(wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines"))
```
This would return:
```
This function
will wrap words
into lines
```
